title: Unidirectional Lightweight Encapsulation
text:
The Unidirectional Lightweight Encapsulation (ULE) is a <a href="Data%20link%20layer">Data link layer</a> protocol for the transportation of network layer packets over <a href="MPEG%20transport%20stream">MPEG transport stream</a>s.
Because of the very low protocol overhead, it is especially suited for IP over Satellite services (where every bit counts). Such a system is for example <a href="DVB-S">DVB-S</a>. However, ULE can also be used in the context of <a href="DVB-C">DVB-C</a> and <a href="DVB-T">DVB-T</a>, theoretically in every system which is based on MPEG transport streams (e.g., <a href="ATSC%20Standards">ATSC</a>).
ULE has been engineered by the <a href="https%3A//web.archive.org/web/20061210055548/http%3A//www.erg.abdn.ac.uk/ip-dvb/">IP over DVB</a> (ipdvb) working group of the <a href="Internet%20Engineering%20Task%20Force">Internet Engineering Task Force</a> (IETF) and has been standardized in RFC 4326.
Another encapsulation method is <a href="Multiprotocol%20Encapsulation">Multiprotocol Encapsulation</a> (MPE) which was developed and standardized by the <a href="Digital%20Video%20Broadcasting">DVB</a> project.
Implementations.
Software: 
<a href="https%3A//www.kernel.org/">Linux Kernel</a>,
